intro: Caricina chordorrhiza, commonly known as the threadroot, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, white to greenish flowers in umbels, typical of the family. Its roots are long and slender, giving it the common name "threadroot." Caricina chordorrhiza is often found in moist, wooded areas and is valued for its medicinal properties in traditional herbal medicine.
